headline: Google Bets Big on a Novel Technology—Iron Batteries
summary: Iron-air batteries can supply a steady supply of energy for 100 hours, far longer than competing batteries for data centers.

headline: Alphabet Ties Data Center Growth To Renewables And Valuation Questions
summary: Alphabet’s Google (NasdaqGS:GOOGL) is expanding its U.S. data center footprint through new long term clean energy agreements with AES Corporation in Texas and Xcel Energy in Minnesota. The projects are expected to add nearly 2 gigawatts of renewable power capacity to support Google’s data centers and related infrastructure. The arrangements include long term power purchase agreements, co located energy assets, and investment aimed at grid reliability and local economic support. For you as...

headline: Google signs AES, Xcel supply deals to meet data-center energy needs
summary: Feb 24 () - Alphabet's Google doubled down on efforts to secure power supply for its data centers across the country by entering into ‌separate agreements with U. utilities, AES Corp and Xcel Energy, on Tuesday.

headline: Google Picks Pine Island For Its Next Mega Data Center

headline: Xcel Energy to power new Google data center in Minnesota
summary: Xcel Energy said on Tuesday it has partnered with Google to power the tech giant's new ‌data center in Pine Island, Minnesota, while contributing 1,900 ‌megawatts of new clean energy to the grid.  U.S. power consumption is expected to ​increase rapidly through this year and the next, driven by the rapid build-out of data centers for artificial intelligence services and cryptocurrency, as well as a shift by homes and businesses toward electric ‌heating and transport.  Xcel said the project would not raise costs for existing customers, as Google will ​pay all ​costs for its new service ​in line with Minnesota's regulatory ‌and legislative requirements for large loads.

Xcel said the project would not raise costs for existing customers, as Google will ​pay all ​costs for its new service ​in line with Minnesota's regulatory ‌and legislative requirements for large loads.
